title: HTML Progress & Meter
description: Display completion status and scalar measurements natively

lessons.title: Progress Bars
lessons.description:
The <progress> element shows task completion. Use value for current progress and max for the total.

Note: This is not a self-closing tag! Write <progress>...</progress> with fallback text inside for older browsers.
lessons.task:
Create a progress bar showing 70% completion:
1. Add a <label> saying 'Download:'
2. Add a <progress> with value="70" and max="100"
lessons.previewBaseCSS: body { font-family: system-ui; padding: 20px; } label { display: block; margin-bottom: 8px; font-weight: 500; } progress { width: 100%; height: 20px; border-radius: 10px; } progress::-webkit-progress-bar { background: #e0e0e0; border-radius: 10px; } progress::-webkit-progress-value { background: linear-gradient(90deg, #4caf50, #8bc34a); border-radius: 10px; } progress::-moz-progress-bar { background: linear-gradient(90deg, #4caf50, #8bc34a); border-radius: 10px; }

validations.message: Add a <kbd><label></kbd> for the progress bar

lessons.title: Indeterminate Progress
lessons.description:
When progress is unknown (like loading), omit the value attribute. This creates an animated indeterminate state.

Useful for network requests or processes with unknown duration.
lessons.task:
Create a loading indicator:
1. Add a <p> saying 'Loading...'
2. Add a <progress> without a value attribute
lessons.previewBaseCSS: body { font-family: system-ui; padding: 20px; } p { margin-bottom: 10px; color: #666; } progress { width: 100%; height: 8px; border-radius: 4px; } progress::-webkit-progress-bar { background: #e0e0e0; border-radius: 4px; }

lessons.title: Meter Gauges
lessons.description:
The <meter> element displays a scalar value within a range. Use it for measurements like disk space, battery, or ratings.

Set low, high, and optimum to define good/bad ranges - the browser colors it accordingly!
lessons.task:
Create a battery level meter:
1. Add a <label> saying 'Battery:'
2. Add a <meter> with:
- value="0.8"
- min="0" and max="1"
- low="0.2" and high="0.8"
- optimum="1"
lessons.previewBaseCSS: body { font-family: system-ui; padding: 20px; } label { display: block; margin-bottom: 8px; font-weight: 500; } meter { width: 100%; height: 25px; }
lessons.solution:
<label for="battery">Battery:</label>
<meter id="battery" value="0.8" min="0" max="1" low="0.2" high="0.8" optimum="1">80%</meter>

validations.message: Set <kbd>low=</kbd>"0.2" to define the low threshold
